Title: (Van Cliburn | 1960 | Live) Brahms: Piano Concerto No.2 in B-flat major, Op.83
Description:
The horn player here begins by demonstrating 'how not to open a concert'. But Cliburn & Rozhdestvensky show how to continue it. Grand and sovereign playing by the extraordinary Texan, who mastered that most rare quality among performing musicians. Not to make their instrument sing, but to make it speak.


Brahms: Piano Concerto No.2 in B-flat major, Op.83
00:00 - I. Allegro non troppo
17:14 - II. Allegro appassionato
25:34 - III. Andante
38:11 - IV. Allegretto grazioso

Van Cliburn, piano
Gennady Rozhdestvensky / All-Union Radio Symphony Orchestra
Source: House Recording

--------------------------
https://classical-pianists.net/
Cliburn's pages: https://classical-pianists.net/generation-ix/van-cliburn/

We have greatly enjoyed these performances over the years and just wish to share them with other music lovers. No copyright infringement is intended; please make contact if there is an issue.

Title: Beethoven Piano Concertos Nos 2, 3 and 4 (Barenboim) - New Philharmonia - Rozhdestvensky (RAH, 1976)
Description:
0:00:00 Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 2
0:31:40 Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 3
1:09:34 Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 4

This concert forms the second of a pair of concerts given in Jan/Feb 1976 in which Daniel Barenboim played all 5 Piano Concertos by Beethoven. He was accompanied by the New Philharmonia Orchestra with Gennady Rozhdestvensky and both concerts were given in the Royal Albert Hall, London. This concert was given on 1 February 1976.

Daniel Barenboim (piano)
New Philharmonia Orchestra
conducted by
Gennady Rozhdestvensky

For more details see https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/service_bbc_radio_three/1976-02-01#at-19.30

This is part of a collection of live "off air" recordings from radio broadcasts I have made since 1970, and I have recently preserved by transferring from tape to digital format. Non of the recordings is derived from a commercial release, nor are they of commercial sound quality. No payment is sought for listening to these recordings, I am sharing them in the hope that they may give pleasure to other music lovers, as they have given pleasure to me. No copyright infringement is intended, please do contact me to allow me to correct the situation should this be the case.

Title: Brahms: Piano Concerto No. 1 - Claudio Arrau, USSR Radio Symphony, Gennadi Rozhdestvensky. Rec. 1968
Description:
00:00 - I. Maestoso
22:42 - II. Adagio
37:02 - III. Rondo. Allegro non troppo
Recorded: 31 May 1968
Recording Venue: Live recording, Grand Hall, Moscow, Russia

Doremi (2) – DHR7890-1
https://www.discogs.com/ru/release/23316479-Claudio-Arrau-Gennadi-Rozhdestvensky-USSR-Radio-Symphony-Orchestra-Claudio-Arrau-in-Moscow

https://www.amazon.ca/1-Claudio-Arrau/dp/B00429UEY2
Luca
5.0 out of 5 stars "Oltre cortina" con un Arrau "live" in gran forma, spalleggiato da un entusiasta Rozhdestvensky.
Reviewed in Italy on December 16, 2011
Verified Purchase
Questi due CD presentano la leggendaria performance del 31 maggio 1968, quando, alla "Sala Grande" di Mosca, Claudio Arrau eseguì entrambi (!) i Concerti per pianoforte di Brahms, accompagnato da Gennadi Rozhdestvensky alla direzione della Grande Orchestra Sinfonica della Radio-Televisione dell'URSS; l'edizione DOREMI è poi arricchita dalle due Sonate per pianoforte di Beethoven, n. 13 in Mib maggiore - Op. 27 n. 1, "Quasi una Fantasia" - e n. 26 in Mib maggiore - Op. 81a, "Les Adieux" -, eseguite durante una non meglio identificata "Live Performance, Moscow, May 1968".

I due concerti di Brahms sono tra le opere più eseguite nell'immenso repertorio di Claudio Arrau. Di conseguenza è naturale che ve ne siano in commercio numerose registrazioni, con: Cameron-PhO-Urania (no. 1 - 1947, studio), Klecki-RCO-Claves (no. 2 - 1959, live), Giulini-PhO-EMI (no. 1 and no. 2 - 1962, studio), Gibson-NSO-BBC Legends (no. 2 - 1963, live), Kubelik-BRSO-Orfeo (no. 1 - 1964, live), Schmidt-Isserstedt-NDR-Kultur (no. 1 - 1966, and no. 2 - 1963, live), Haitink-RCO-Philips (no. 1 and no. 2 - 1969, studio), Markevitch-FNO-INA (no. 2 - 1976, live), Izquierdo-SPO-New Arts (no. 1 - 1984, live DVD), etc.

Perché quindi acquistare proprio o anche questa edizione? La risposta più forte ce la fornisce secondo me Gennadi Rozhdestvensky stesso, in una sua breve intervista contenuta nel DVD "The Art of Piano" (NVC ART, 1999). Rozhdestvensky - a sua volta uno dei più grandi direttori della nostra epoca -, che aveva già lavorato col grande pianista in passato, quando parla della sua collaborazione professionale con Arrau, afferma esplicitamente che gli sembrava di lavorare con Brahms in persona!
Dunque quale migliore biglietto da visita per queste esecuzioni? Si tratta poi di registrazioni live (in cui Arrau è spesso più "brillante" o "slegato" che in studio), con Arrau in grandissima forma. In generale il 1968 si colloca per Arrau in un ottimo periodo, che coniuga un virtuosismo perfettamente integro con una visione interpretativa sempre più profonda e meditata ed un suono di raro calore ed estensione timbrica, ma sempre pulitissimo.

Rozhdestvensky, ovviamente, per quanto detto, entra in evidente empatia con l'ammirato solista, lo asseconda al meglio, tuttavia senza soggezione e tutt'altro che servilmente, anzi estraendo dalla partitura sonorità e respiri non spesso uditi, in parte dovuti anche alla particolare timbrica dell'orchestra, che affronta l'opera, per così dire, secondo scuola e tradizione proprie.
Il risultato è che entrambi i concerti "suonano" in maniera alquanto differente dalle registrazioni "ufficiali" per Philips dell'anno seguente, fornendo anche un interessantissimo termine di paragone. Le due esecuzioni moscovite sono estremamente convincenti: brillanti, ma profonde e sentite, calde e coinvolgenti, ma nitide e pulite. Il pubblico evidentemente gradisce e dimostra il proprio incondizionato apprezzamento con caloroso entusiasmo.

Altrettanto convincenti risultano le superbe esecuzioni delle due Sonate beethoveniane, accolte dal pubblico altrettanto calorosamente.

La resa sonora non è così lontana dagli standard dell'epoca; ovviamente non raggiunge i livelli qualitativi dell'edizione in studio per Philips, 1969, ma è ravvivata da un suo particolare senso di "living presence". In altri termini, consente di vivere appieno e di chiaramente percepire la particolare atmosfera dell'evento.

In conclusione, tutti i fattori sopra evidenziati contribuiscono ad attribuire a questa edizione un suo particolare e distintivo "aroma", il che, secondo me è un ottimo motivo per l'acquisto. Insomma, i supporter di Arrau seguiranno più che volentieri il loro interprete preferito in questa eccezionale e trionfale trasferta "oltre cortina".
Comunque, in termini più generali, tutte le esecuzioni qui raccolte da DOREMI sono a mio parere pienamente legittimate ad entrare nel novero delle migliori tra quelle registrate di sempre e quindi ben si collocano nella serie editoriale "Legendary Treasures".

Title: [Remastered] David Oistrakh, G. Rozhdestvensky: J. Sibelius Violin Concerto in d minor, Op. 47, 1966
Description:
This is one of the best rendition of Sibelius Violin Concerto, performed by the legendary violinist David Oistrakh.
This remastered version with the stereo sound brings a more realistic sound of Oistrakh compares to the original recording,  I also did the volume dynamic adjustment of the orchestra.
Unfortunately there are no high quality recordings on YouTube, but I managed to find it on Bilibili. The quality is probably the same as the DVD released by EMI in 2004.

Original video:
https://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1QV411m7qG
The Sibelius Violin Concerto starts at 43:25 in this video

00:00 - 1st movement
14:21 - 2nd movement
22:50 - 3rd movement

Jean Sibelius: Violin Concerto in d minor, Op. 47
David Oistrakh - Violin
Gennady Rozhdestvensky - Conductor
The Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra
Live Recording at the Tchaikovsky Hall, Moscow, November 12, 1966
Remastered by Li Wangping in 2022

Thank you all for your support! If you like the video please give a thumb up, leave a comment, share the video and subscribe to my channel for more high quality remastered classical music recordings!

Title: Gennady Rozhdestvensky: Cherubini - La prisonnière, 'Overture'
Description:
Gennady Nikolayevich Rozhdestvensky (Генна́дий Никола́евич Рожде́ственский) (born 4 May 1931) is a Russian conductor. Rozhdestvensky is considered a versatile conductor and a highly cultured musician with a supple stick technique. In moulding his interpretations, he gives a clear idea of the structural outlines and emotional content of a piece, combined with a performing style which melds logic, intuition and spontaneity. He has been praised for his efficient rehearsals which he keeps short, and is noted for his habit of walking around the stage while conducting and not using a podium, even at concerts. Conductor Rozhdestvensky is featured in the documentary Notes interdites : scènes de la vie musicale en Russie Soviétique (Bruno Monsaingeon, 2004, 55m 44s, English title: "The Red Baton"), which examines the hardships faced by musicians in the Soviet Union under Stalinism. In it, he describes the political situation and its impact on his life, as well as those of Shostakovich, Prokofiev, Stravinsky, Richter and other colleagues. The role of Tikhon Khrennikov, Secretary of the Union of Soviet Composers, is discussed extensively. On a lighter note, the documentary features Rozhdestvensky discussing the art of conducting, and includes footage of masterclasses, rehearsals with students from the Moscow Conservatory and Zürich's Tonhalle orchestra, as well as snippets of Rozhdestvensky conducting Shostakovich's 7th Symphony, Tchaikovsky's Romeo and Juliet, and Alfred Schnittke's Dead Souls... http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gennady_Rozhdestvensky


A link to this wonderful artists personal Website: http://www.rayfieldallied.com/artists/gennady-rozhdestvensky/


Please Enjoy!

I send my kind and warm regards,

Title: Igor Stravinsky - The Rite Of Spring: Gennady Rozhdestvensky conducting the LSO in 1987
Description:
Gennady Rozhdestvensky conducting Le Sacre du Printemps with the London Symphony Orchestra in February 1987.

This is one of three Rozhdestvensky/LSO performances in my archive, and the one in which the recording quality is unfortunately lower than the others. This recording was made on cassette stock that has not stood the test of time and has degraded somewhat, but hopefully you'll agree that the power of the performance still comes through.

Part 1: The Adoration of the Earth
Part 2: The Sacrifice 16:40

This channel is not associated in any way with the London Symphony Orchestra, or its own CD label, LSO LIVE. These are recordings made by a LSO fan over a period of 40 years from 1977, and are not rips of LSO LIVE recordings. I have greatly enjoyed these performances over the years and just wish to share them with other music lovers. No copyright infringement is intended; please make contact if there is an issue.

Title: Prokofiev - Incidental music for Hamlet Op.77 (Rozhdestvensky)
Description:
Sergei Prokofiev wrote nine scenes for the 1937-38 Leningrad production of Shakespeare's play, which he then thought of turning into an opera, but the project never materialized. Instead he reworked it into a concert suite that was never performed during his lifetime (it was premiered by Rozhdestvensky in 1957). 

(Prokofiev arranged the third dance for the piano; played masterfully by Vedernikov here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ynq002S_QB8 )  


1. Fanfares. Ghost of Hamlet's Father 
2. Fanfares. Claudio’s March  3:16 
3. Fanfares. Pantomime 5:39 
4. Ophelia’s First Song  8:33  
5. Ophelia’s Second Song 11:03 
6. Ophelia’s Third Song    13:39 
7. Ophelia’s Fourth Song  15:07 
8. Gravedigger’s Song   16:38
9. Fanfares. Fortinbras’s March  18:58

Bass – Anatoli Safiulin
Soprano – Natalia Gerasimova

The USSR Ministry Of Culture Symphony Orchestra conducted by Gennadi Rozhdestvensky 

Recorded in 1988

Title: Rozhdestvensky conducts Glinka's 'Ruslan and Lyudmila' Overture
Description: Gennadi Rozhdestvensky was appointed the Chief Conductor of the BBC Symphony from 1978-1981. He gave many splendid concerts with them and happily several were televised. In the 1981 Proms Season at London's Royal Albert Hall, he opened one of his programmes with the lively Glinka overture heard here. It comes from a DVD release on the 'ICA Classics' label (Catalogue No. ICAD 5027).

This channel is not associated in any way with the London Symphony Orchestra, or its own CD label, LSO LIVE. Title: Tchaikovsky 'The Maid of Orleans' - Introduction, Hymn & Finale Act 1 - Rozhdestvensky conducts
Description: Tchaikovsky's "The Maid of Orleans," based on the story of Joan of Arc, is seldom performed (has it ever been given at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden?) yet nevertheless contains some wonderful music. In this 1971 'Melodiya' recording, recently reissued on CD (finally) we hear the Introduction, followed by a cadenza on the solo flute, which then leads into a Girls Chorus. This is followed by a Hymn in which Joan calls for God's mercy. In the Act 1 Finale a Chorus of Angels beseeches her to become the Saviour of France. Irena Arkhipova sings Joan and Gennady Rozhdestvensky is the conductor of his Moscow forces. Note that since this was uploaded from the LP set, Melodya has issued the recording on CD.

Description:
Obviously not all of you will celebrate Christmas, may I however wish you all peace and good health in these troubled times with the hope that 2024 brings more positive news in the world.

Tchaikovsky's The Nutcracker is traditionally performed at Christmas in the UK and hence I thought this recording would be appropriate to upload today. This performance was taken from a BBC Promenade Concert given on 27 July 1981 in the Royal Albert Hall, London

Gennady Rozhdestvensky

Title: The MV Tapes - Matthijs Vermeulen: Symphony 2, °1920 (Rozhdestvensky)
Description:
Matthijs Vermeulen (°1888-1967) was the central composer of the Holland Festival of 1997 during which all symphonic works were performed by various major orchestras of the Netherlands (with the exception of the Concertgebouw Orchestra which has statutorily banned this composer from its programmes).
As 2017 and 2018 are both "Vermeulen years" (in 2017 it is 50 years ago the composer died, in 2018 it will the composer's 130'th birthday) I would like to pay my homage by presenting this series of performances to an international audience. The installments will be published in the order the concerts were given.

Now: Symphony 2, "Prélude à la nouvelle journée", by the Residentie Orchestra conducted by Gennady Rozhdestvensky, a live recording from June 24, 1997.
For more information on the composer, visit the official website
https://matthijsvermeulen.nl/en/life-and-works/
More information on Symphony 2:
https://matthijsvermeulen.nl/en/compositions/symphony/second-symphony-prelude-a-la-nouvelle-journee/


!! CONCERT HALL, PERFORMERS, BROADCAST, ARCHIVING AND PRESERVATION WERE ALL FINANCED WITH PUBLIC MONEY !!

Title: Vaughan Williams - London Symphony: Gennady Rozhdestvensky conducts the LSO in 1985
Description:
A fascinating and committed performance of RVW's 'A London Symphony' with the LSO under the baton of one of the leading Russian conductors of the day, Gennady Rozhdestvensky, as part of that year's City of London Festival on 8th July 1985.

1. Lento, allegro risoluto 0:00
2. Lento 14:54
3. Scherzo, allegro vivace 26:35
4. Andante con moto, maestoso alla marcia (quasi lento) 33:29

This channel is not associated in any way with the London Symphony Orchestra, or its own CD label, LSO LIVE. These are recordings made by a LSO fan over a period of 40 years from 1977, and are not rips of LSO LIVE recordings. I have greatly enjoyed these performances over the years and just wish to share them with other music lovers. No copyright infringement is intended; please make contact if there is an issue.

Title: Viktoria Postnikova plays Rachmaninoff Piano Concerto no. 1 - video 1979
Description:
a young and beautiful Viktoria Postnikova playing Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto no. 1, op. 1, with the BBC SO under Gennady Rozhdestvensky, live at the Proms on 31 August 1979. Postnikova studied with Yakov Flier and is married to Rozhdestvensky.

**This video is intended for viewing and sharing only without any commercial purpose. If for any reason the holder wishes to have it removed, please contact me before making a claim and I will take it down immediately**

Виктория Постникова - Рахманинов - Геннадий Рождественский

Title: Viktoria Postnikova plays Strauss Burleske - video 1989
Description:
Viktoria Postnikova playing Richard Strauss's Burleske with the State Academic SO under Gennady Rozhdestvensky, live in Moscow in 1989. Skip to 00:47 for the start. Postnikova studied with Yakov Flier. She shared second at the 1966 Leeds competition, shared first at the 1968 Vianna da Motta competition, and shared third at the 1970 Tchaikovsky competition.

Виктория Постникова - Рихард Штраус - Бурлеска для фортепиано с оркестром - Геннадий Рождественский - Burlesque

Description:
The State Symphony Orchestra of the USSR Ministry of Culture
dir. Gennady Rozhdestvensky
Recording : 1984
c & p Melodiya Records

Title: Walton Symphony No. 1 - Rozhdestvensky conducts
Description: Sir William Walton's 1st Symphony was given its first complete performance by the BBC Symphony Orchestra under Sir Hamilton Harty in 1935. In 1979, under its then principal conductor Gennady Rozhdestvensky, the BBC SO took the work to Czechoslovakia where it was played during the Spring Festival in Prague. We hear it again now with all due acknowledgements to Czech Radio.

Title: Walton Symphony No. 2 - BBC Symphony Orchestra - Gennady Rozhdestvensky (BBC Maida Vale, 1980)
Description:
This is a recording of Walton's lesser known 2nd Symphony broadcast on 13 October 1980 and given in the BBC Maida Vale Studio.

BBC Symphony Orchestra
conducted by
Gennady Rozhdestvensky

For more details see: https://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/schedules/service_bbc_radio_three/1980-10-13#at-20.15

This is part of a collection of live "off air" recordings from radio broadcasts I have made since 1970, and I have recently preserved by transferring from tape to digital format. None of the recordings is derived from a commercial release, nor are they of commercial sound quality. No payment is sought for listening to these recordings, I am sharing them in the hope that they may give pleasure to other music lovers, as they have given pleasure to me. No copyright infringement is intended, please do contact me to allow me to correct the situation should this be the case.
